They longer waiting periods are for those who are not in dire need of treatment.
My sister was suspected to have brain cancer a few years back. She was having a scan within hours of them suggesting it (went from GP right to the hospital). That is not a long wait at all. If they found something, they would have started to deal with it quickly.
The only time you are really going to be waiting around for healthcare is if you are not at immediate risk of dying. A broken arm, for instance, may take a week or so to have an operation carried out. That is not too long. A E may take a few hours to get seen (depending on how busy they are), but they will prioritise people based on their condition/age.
I have never found wait times to be an issue. Certainly, the fact that you are paying LESS money would help to counter any of those wait time issues anyway.

And South Africa is actually looking to change that. It is more difficult for them, though. The money is not actually 'there', whereas America would just require a little bit of a shift in the way in spends the money that it already has, as well as negotiating with drug companies. It would be easier for America to implement universal healthcare than South Africa, but South Africa is still trying.

The only time a generic drug will be used is if the original creator of the drug is not willing to budge on their prices. Guess what? When they realise they amount of money they are losing by not getting into that market, they budge. If the NHS (for example) sticks with a generic drug then it is because it has been proven to be effective.

Oh, and it would not cost $100,000 under single payer because now there are not companies trying to make as much money as possible from your health. Because life expectancy in the US is lower, and cancer survival rates in the USA are ever so slightly higher (like 1 person per 100,000). However, it is likely that 'better' healthcare is not the reason.

You are aware that under single payer, the costs for everybody gets lower, yes?
How much do you pay in insurance in America each year? Quite a lot, I imagine. Then you have the bit on top of that.
On a standard wage in the UK, I spend 2,000 out of my taxes each year. This means no excess. No expensive medication etc. etc. AND if I do not use it, I know that somebody else is benefitting from the money that I paid in.
Oh, and before you say "but healthcare is better in America". Survival rates for cancer are a teeny bit higher in the US than in the UK. I think it is a difference of 1 person per 100,000. This is a tiny figure and it is likely that there is other stuff to be considered here not just the quality of healthcare.
If you have cancer, you are not going to be kept around waiting for treatment in the UK. They will start as soon as possible. Somebody thought my sister had brain cancer. Did she wait weeks for a scan? No, they took her from the GP to the hospital within an hour.
It is also worth noting that, on the whole, US has a lower life expectancy than Western Countries, which means the healthcare does seem to be better there.
